what: Forecasting with Bayesian Panel Vector Autoregressions
title: Forecasting with Bayesian Panel Vector Autoregressions
text: R package Forecasting Bayesian Panel Vector Autoregressions Provides Bayesian estimation forecasting dynamic panel data using Bayesian Panel Vector Autoregressions hierarchical prior distributions. model includes country-specific VARs share global prior distribution. prior expected value, country’s system follows global VAR country-invariant parameters. flexibility provided hierarchical prior structure retains Minnesota prior interpretation global VAR features estimated prior covariance matrices, shrinkage, persistence levels. Bayesian forecasting developed models including exogenous variables, allowing conditional forecasts given future trajectories variables restricted forecasts assuring rates forecasted stay positive less 100. package implements model specification, estimation, forecasting routines, facilitating coherent workflows reproducibility. Beautiful plots, informative summary functions, extensive documentation complement . extraordinary computational speed achieved thanks employing frontier econometric numerical techniques algorithms written C++. bpvars package aligned regarding objects, workflows, code structure R packages bsvars Woźniak (2024) bsvarSIGNs Wang & Woźniak (2024), constitute integrated toolset.

Hierarchical Panel VAR model features sophisticated hierarchical prior structure grants model flexibility, interpretability, improved forecasting performance. country-specific parameters follow prior distribution , mean value, represents global VAR model global autoregressive parameter matrix global error term covariance matrix S: See details presentation
code: Yc = Xc Ac + Ec         (VAR equation) Ec | Xc ~ MN(0, I, Sc)       (error term normality) Yc = Xc A + Ec          (VAR equation)   Ec | Xc ~ MN(0, I, S)        (error term normality)

what: Start your Bayesian analysis of data
title: Forecasting with Bayesian Panel Vector Autoregressions
text: beginnings easy ABC: bpvars package supports simplified workflow using |> pipe: Now, ’re ready analyse model forecasts!
code: library(bpvars)                                     # load the package  spec = specify_bvarPANEL$new(                           # specify the model   ilo_dynamic_panel                                     # data )  burn = estimate(spec, S = 10000)                        # run the burn-in post = estimate(burn, S = 10000)                        # estimate the model  fore = forecast(                                        # forecast the model    post,                                                 # estimation output   horizon = 6                                           # forecast horizon )  plot(fore, "COL", main = "Forecasts for Colombia") summary(fore, "COL")$variable2  post |>                                                 # estimation output   compute_variance_decompositions(horizon = 6) |>       # compute variance decompositions   plot(which_c = "COL")                                 # plot variance decompositions ilo_dynamic_panel |>                                    # data   specify_bvarPANEL$new() |>                            # specify the model   estimate(S = 10000) |>                                # run the burn-in   estimate(S = 10000) -> post                           # estimate the model  post |> forecast(                                       # forecast the model    horizon = 6                                           # forecast horizon ) |> plot("COL", main = "Forecasts for Colombia")

title: Forecasting with Bayesian Panel Vector Autoregressions — bpvars-package
text: Provides Bayesian estimation forecasting dynamic panel data using Bayesian Panel Vector Autoregressions hierarchical prior distributions. models include country-specific VARs share global prior distribution extend model Jarociński (2010) doi:10.1002/jae.1082 . prior expected value, country's system follows global VAR country-invariant parameters. flexibility provided hierarchical prior structure retains Minnesota prior interpretation global VAR features estimated prior covariance matrices, shrinkage, persistence levels. Bayesian forecasting developed models including exogenous variables, allowing conditional forecasts given future trajectories variables restricted forecasts assuring rates forecasted stay positive less 100. package implements model specification, estimation, forecasting routines, facilitating coherent workflows reproducibility. also includes automated pseudo---sample forecasting computation forecasting performance measures. Beautiful plots, informative summary functions, extensive documentation complement . extraordinary computational speed achieved thanks employing frontier econometric numerical techniques algorithms written 'C++'. title: Forecasting with Bayesian Panel Vector Autoregressions — bpvars-package
text:
package provides set functions predictive analysis Bayesian Hierarchical Panel Vector Autoregression. Model. model specification initiated using function specify_bvarPANEL creates object class BVARPANEL containing prior specification, starting values estimation, data matrices, setup Monte Carlo Markov Chain sampling algorithm. model features country-specific Vector Autoregressive (VAR) equation N dependent variables T_c observations country c. equation given $$\mathbf{Y}_c = \mathbf{}_c\mathbf{X}_c + \mathbf{E}_c$$ \(\mathbf{Y}_c\) T_c x N matrix dependent variables country c, \(\mathbf{X}_c\) T_c x K matrix explanatory variables, \(\mathbf{E}_c\) T_c x N matrix error terms, \(\mathbf{}_c\) NxK matrix country-specific autoregressive slope coefficients parameters deterministic terms \(\mathbf{X}_c\). parameter matrix \(\mathbf{}_c\) includes autoregressive matrices capturing effects lagged vectors dependent variables lags 1 p, constant term set exogenous variables. error terms periods zero conditional mean conditional covariance given NxN matrix \(\mathbf{\Sigma}\). errors jointly normally distributed serially uncorrelated. assumptions summarised using matrix-variate normal distribution (see Woźniak, 2016): $$\mathbf{E}_c \sim MN(\mathbf{0}_{T_c x N}, \mathbf{\Sigma}, \mathbf{}_{T_c})$$ identity matrix \(\mathbf{}_{T_c}\) order T_c joint normality imply serial autocorrelation. Matrix \(\mathbf{0}_{T_c x N}\) denotes T_c x N matrix zeros. Global Prior Distributions. Hierarchical Panel VAR model features sophisticated hierarchical prior structure grants model flexibility, interpretability, improved forecasting performance. country-specific parameters follow prior distribution , mean value, represents global VAR model global autoregressive parameter matrix \(\mathbf{}\) dimension KxN NxN global covariance matrix \(\mathbf{\Sigma}\): $$\mathbf{Y}_c = \mathbf{AX}_c + \mathbf{E}_c$$ global VAR model prior mean represented parameters matrix-variate normal inverted Wishart distribution (see Woźniak, 2016) given : $$\mathbf{}_c, \mathbf{\Sigma}_c | \mathbf{}, \mathbf{V}, \mathbf{\Sigma}, 
u \sim MNIW(\mathbf{}, \mathbf{V}, (N - 
u - 1)\mathbf{\Sigma}, 
u)$$ \(V\) KxK column-specific covariance matrix, \((N - 
u - 1)\mathbf{\Sigma}\) row-specific matrix, \(
u > N+1\) degrees--freedom parameter. parameters prior distribution feature prior distributions estimated. prior distributions given : $$\mathbf{} | \mathbf{V}, m, w, s \sim MN (m\underline{\mathbf{M}}, \mathbf{V}, s\underline{\mathbf{S}} ) $$ KxN mean matrix \(m\underline{\mathbf{M}}\), KxK column-specific covariance matrix \(\mathbf{V}\), NxN matrix row-specific covariance \(s\underline{\mathbf{S}}\). global error term covariance matrix, \(\mathbf{\Sigma}\), follows Wishart distribution NxN scale matrix \(s\underline{\mathbf{S}}_\Sigma\) shape parameter \(\underline{\mu}_\Sigma\) $$\mathbf{\Sigma} | s, 
u \sim W(s\underline{\mathbf{S}}_\Sigma,\underline{\mu}_\Sigma)$$ Prior Distributions. column-specific covariance \(\mathbf{V}\) follows inverse-Wishart distribution scale \(w\underline{\mathbf{W}}\) shape \(\underline{\eta}\): $$\mathbf{V} | w \sim IW(w\underline{\mathbf{W}}, \underline{\eta})$$ shape parameter \(
u\) follows exponential distribution mean \(\underline\lambda\): $$
u \sim\exp(\underline\lambda)$$ Finally, priors remaining scalar hyper-parameters : $$m \sim N(\underline{\mu}_m, \underline{\sigma}_m^2)$$ $$w \sim G(\underline{s}_w, \underline{}_w)$$ $$s \sim IG2 (\underline{s}_s, \underline{
u}_s)$$ prior hyper-parameters note grouped : fixed denoted using underscore, e.g.  \(\underline{\mathbf{M}}\), \(\underline{\mu}_\Sigma\),  \(\underline{
u}_s\). hyper-parameters must fixed  default values set initiating model specification using function  specify_bvarPANEL. values can accesses  generated object element prior can modified user. estimated featuring underscore notation, e.g.  \(\mathbf{}\), \(\mathbf{\Sigma}\), \(m\). hyper-parameters  estimated posterior draws available object  generated estimation running function estimate. Estimation. package implements Bayesian estimation using Gibbs sampler. algorithm provides sample random draws posterior distribution parameters model. posterior distribution defined Bayes' Rule stating posterior distribution parameters given data proportional likelihood function prior distribution parameters: $$p(\mathbf{	heta} | \mathbf{Y}) \propto L(\mathbf{	heta}; \mathbf{Y}) p(\mathbf{	heta})$$ \(\mathbf{	heta}\) collects parameters model estimated. iterations single draw parameters model, including estimated hyper-parameters, obtained. Bayesian procedure estimates jointly parameters model implemented estimate.BVARPANEL estimate.PosteriorBVARPANEL functions. Forecasting. package implements Bayesian forecasting providing sample draws joint predictive density defined joint density future unknown values predicted, \(\mathbf{Y}_f\), given data, \(\mathbf{Y}\) closely following Karlsson (2013): $$p(\mathbf{Y}_f | \mathbf{Y})$$ package offers possibility : forecasting models exogenous variables given provided   future values exogenous variables. conditional predictions given provided future projections   variables. trucated forecasts variables represents rates   interval \([0,100]\). forecasting performed using function forecast.PosteriorBVARPANEL.

code: # Basic estimation and forecasting example ############################################################ specification = specify_bvarPANEL$new(ilo_dynamic_panel[1:5]) # specify the model burn_in       = estimate(specification, S = 5)          # run the burn-in; title: Bayesian estimation of a Bayesian Hierarchical Panel Vector Autoregression with fixed or estimated country grouping — estimate.BVARGROUPPANEL
text: Bayesian Hierarchical Panel Vector Autoregressive model fixed estimated country grouping estimated using Gibbs sampler. estimation procedure parameters model estimated jointly. list parameters model includes: \(\mathbf{}_c\) KxN country-specific autoregressive  parameters matrix countries \(c = 1,\dots,C\) \(\mathbf{\Sigma}_c\) NxN country-specific covariance  matrix countries \(c = 1,\dots,C\) \(\mathbf{}\) KxN global autoregressive parameters matrix \(\mathbf{\Sigma}\) NxN global covariance matrix \(\mathbf{V}\) KxK covariance matrix prior global autoregressive parameters \(\nu\) prior degrees freedom parameter \(m\) prior average global persistence parameter \(w\) prior scaling parameter \(s\) prior scaling parameter Parameters \(\mathbf{}_c\) \(\mathbf{\Sigma}_c\) subject country grouping sets group-specific values. Gibbs sampler algorithm sample random draws posterior distribution parameters model given data. algorithm briefly explained example two-parameter model parameters \(\theta_1\) \(\theta_2\). order sample joint posterior distribution \(p(\theta_1,\theta_2|\mathbf{Y})\) Gibbs sampler proceeds sampling full-conditional posterior distributions parameter given data parameters, denoted \(p(\theta_1|\theta_2,\mathbf{Y})\) \(p(\theta_2|\theta_1,\mathbf{Y})\). distributions available derivations form distributions easy sample random numbers . obtain S draws posterior distribution: Set initial values parameters \(\theta_2^{(0)}\) s iterations: Sample \(\theta_1^{(s)}\) \(p(\theta_1|\theta_2^{(s-1)},\mathbf{Y})\) Sample \(\theta_2^{(s)}\) \(p(\theta_2|\theta_1^{(s)},\mathbf{Y})\) Repeat step 2. S times. Return \(\{\theta_1^{(s)},\theta_2^{(s)}\}_{s=1}^{S}\) sample drawn posterior distribution \(p(\theta_1,\theta_2|\mathbf{Y})\). estimate() function returns draws posterior distribution parameters hierarchical panel VAR model listed . Thinning. Thinning procedure reduce dependence returned sample posterior distribution. obtained returning every thin draw final sample. procedure reduces number draws returned estimate() function.

title: Forecasting using Hierarchical Panel Vector Autoregressions — forecast.PosteriorBVARGROUPPRIORPANEL
text: package provides range options regarding forecasting procedure. dependent model forecast specifications include Bayesian forecasting many periods ahead, conditional forecasting, forecasting models exogenous variables. One-period-ahead predictive density. model assumptions provided documentation bpvars determine country-specific one-period ahead conditional predictive density unknown vector \(\mathbf{y}_{c.t+1}\) given data available time \(t\) parameters model. multivariate normal mean \(\mathbf{}_c' \mathbf{x}_{c.t+1}\) covariance matrix \(\mathbf{\Sigma}_c\) $$p(\mathbf{y}_{c.t+1} | \mathbf{x}_{c.t+1}, \mathbf{}_c, \mathbf{\Sigma}_c) = N_N(\mathbf{}_c' \mathbf{x}_{c.t+1}, \mathbf{\Sigma}_c)$$ \(\mathbf{x}_{c.t+1}\) includes lagged values \(\mathbf{y}_{c.t+1}\), constant term, , potentially, exogenous variables specified user. Bayesian predictive density. one-period ahead predictive density used sample joint predictive density unknown future values. predictive density defined joint density \(\mathbf{y}_{c.t+h}\) horizons \(h = 1,\dots,H\), \(H\) corresponds value argument horizon, given data available time \(t\): $$p( \mathbf{y}_{c.T_c + H}, \dots, \mathbf{y}_{c.T_c + 1} | \mathbf{Y}_c, \mathbf{X}_c) = \int p(\mathbf{y}_{c.T_c + H}, \dots, \mathbf{y}_{c.T_c + 1} | \mathbf{Y}_c, \mathbf{X}_c, \mathbf{}_c, \boldsymbol\Sigma_c) p( \mathbf{}_c, \boldsymbol\Sigma_c | \mathbf{Y}_c, \mathbf{X}_c) d(\mathbf{}_c, \boldsymbol\Sigma_c)$$ Therefore, Bayesian forecast depend parameter values parameters integrated respect posterior distribution. Consequently, Bayesian forecasts incorporate uncertainty respect estimation. Sampling density facilitated using draws posterior density sequential sampling one-period ahead predictive density. Conditional forecasting variables given future values remaining variables implemented following Waggoner Zha (1999) based conditional normal density given future projections variables created basing one-period ahead predictive density. Exogenous variables.
